20.text: sheetwash. The outcropping Archaean consists largely of low greenschist facies fine-

21.text: grained metabasalts, very minor interflow metasediments, occasional dolerite sills, acid

22.text: intrusive porphyries and minor acid volcanics. The general stratigraphy strikes east-west,

28.text: section of the leases and appears to have a sinistral offset. Neither the dyke nor the

29.text: offsetting sinistral fault are observed in outcrop.

text:
road to Mertondale from Leonora, and thence by station tracks via Karrajong Bore along
 the track to Maurice Bore.
 Tenement P37/4395 comprises 80 hectares, and the tenement (P37/4397) comprises 196
 hectares making a total of 276 hectares.
 Some 50% of the tenements are covered with Tertiary and Recent colluvium, talus silt and
 sheetwash. The outcropping Archaean consists largely of low greenschist facies fine-
 grained metabasalts, very minor interflow metasediments, occasional dolerite sills, acid
 intrusive porphyries and minor acid volcanics. The general stratigraphy strikes east-west,
 with occasional near vertical cleavage orientations observed at around 150°. The
 tenement forms part of the core of a major SSW plunging regional fold known as the
 Benalia Anticline. In keeping with this, the rocks in the district young in a general southerly
 direction. Folding in this region is only rarely encountered. A prominent east-west
 Proterozoic dyke is picked up in aerial and ground magnetics, running though the lower
 section of the leases and appears to have a sinistral offset. Neither the dyke nor the
 offsetting sinistral fault are observed in outcrop.
 5. EXPLORATION HISTORY 1997 - 2006
 Previous mining activity in these tenements has been largely via metal detecting and the
 use of a large 25 tph dryblower. Exploration methods involved sampling and dollying. A
 major regional-scale geochemistry program was undertaken in 1991 by Son’s of Gwalia
 (reference WAGS WAMEX Open File Register, item number I 4721 Microfiche 06781 Title
 Kurrajong Bore gold exploration).

were mixed but seemed consistently lower than previous materials. Samples were
 generally collected from calcareous soils in the first metre.
 Activities covered in the 2004-2005: additional soil geochemistry, re-assessment and
 reconciliation, detailed 1:5000 scale lithological, structural and regolith mapping, sampling,
 dollying and panning of vein quartz and nodular & pisolitic laterite scree and minor metal
 Activities covered in the 2005-2006: The original ground magnetic data was re-contoured
 to highlight subtleties swamped by the magnitude of the adjacent Proterozoic dyke.
 Detailed ground magnetic traverses were undertaken to better define buried drainage
 patterns and these were followed up with single geophone seismic traverses to verify
 buried drainage features.
 6. 2006-2007 EXPLORATION PROGRAMME
 The relationship between anomalous soil gold levels and soil carbonate in the eastern half
 of the lease area is well documented. An anomalous gold area some 500 x 2000 metres
 has been defined largely by auger sampling of calcareous soils and calcrete within the
 transported cover that dominates the north-south drainage of this area (see Figure 1).
 A problem exist however in that not all the samples collected were from calcareous
 horizons and hence those samples not selected from such horizons in transported cover
 will give low gold values, possibly unrepresentative of the gold values in the underlying
 rock. The result is a mix of soil assay values of varying reliability and a possibly poor
 definition of any underlying gold distribution.
 In order to improve the definition and reliability of the soil gold pattern, a mobile metal ion
 (MMI), soil sampling program has been devised to resample the same grid.
 Some 173 soil samples have been collected from largely transported alluvial and colluvial
 cover overlying a buried drainage channel within Archaean greenstone basalts.
 Sampling was shallow (less than 10 cm), and sieved to less than 5 mm. pH
 measurements of the samples are generally (90%) slightly acid, but cover the range 6.0 to

9.text: The original soil auger data is from four source materials:

10.text: Calcareous soils and calcrete sampled within transported cover

11.text: Calcareous soils & calcrete sampled above bedrock and not in transported cover

12.text: Non-calcareous soils lacking calcrete within transported cover

13.text: Non-calcareous soils lacking calcrete, not in transported cover

14.text: The samples selected for normal soil analysis in calcareous sample media are likely to

15.text: show elevated metal values if located above or near mineralisation (in the case of both

16.text: transported cover and in-situ soils). Samples from transported cover locations, not

17.text: recovered from calcareous sample media, will show very low or background values only,

19.text: The samples selected for MMI analysis from the same locations sourced in calcareous

20.text: sample media are likely to show only low metal values (as the calcareous material is likely

21.text: to have scavenged all the metal). Elevated metal values should be recorded for samples

22.text: located above or near mineralisation (in the case of both transported cover and in-situ

23.text: soils), but will give background values only above non-mineralised ground.

24.text: An attempt will be made to normalise and then combine the two sample data sets by

25.text: determining meaningful background threshold values for both the MMI and the traditional

26.text: soil data sets and then calculating appropriate response ratios (the ratio of enrichment

27.text: over background values) in both cases. As a result there will be two data values for each

28.text: sample site for each element and only the higher values will be plotted on the one map to

29.text: hopefully give the most meaningful result.

text:
Data analysis method
 The original soil auger data is from four source materials:
 Calcareous soils and calcrete sampled within transported cover
 Calcareous soils & calcrete sampled above bedrock and not in transported cover
 Non-calcareous soils lacking calcrete within transported cover
 Non-calcareous soils lacking calcrete, not in transported cover
 The samples selected for normal soil analysis in calcareous sample media are likely to
 show elevated metal values if located above or near mineralisation (in the case of both
 transported cover and in-situ soils). Samples from transported cover locations, not
 recovered from calcareous sample media, will show very low or background values only,
 even with underlying mineralisation.
 The samples selected for MMI analysis from the same locations sourced in calcareous
 sample media are likely to show only low metal values (as the calcareous material is likely
 to have scavenged all the metal). Elevated metal values should be recorded for samples
 located above or near mineralisation (in the case of both transported cover and in-situ
 soils), but will give background values only above non-mineralised ground.
 An attempt will be made to normalise and then combine the two sample data sets by
 determining meaningful background threshold values for both the MMI and the traditional
 soil data sets and then calculating appropriate response ratios (the ratio of enrichment
 over background values) in both cases. As a result there will be two data values for each
 sample site for each element and only the higher values will be plotted on the one map to
 hopefully give the most meaningful result.

9.text: To analyse, plot and interpret the MMI soil data, in associations with the existing auger

10.text: sampled data sampling the calcareous media from site within transported cover.

text:
To analyse, plot and interpret the MMI soil data, in associations with the existing auger
 sampled data sampling the calcareous media from site within transported cover.
